holidays.name: National Catfish Day
holidays.description: A day to celebrate the delicious and bony freshwater fish known as catfish. Whether fried, grilled, or smoked, catfish is a Southern U.S. favorite and enjoyed by fish lovers everywhere!
holidays.origin: Established in the U.S. in 1987 to promote the aquaculture industry, especially catfish farming.
holidays.funFact: Catfish have no scales and their 'whiskers' called barbels help them sense food in muddy waters.

holidays.name: Log Cabin Day
holidays.description: This day celebrates the humble log cabin, a symbol of pioneer spirit and early American frontier life, reminding us of simpler times and rugged self-sufficiency.
holidays.origin: Commemorates the construction of the first log cabins by early European settlers in America during the 1600s.
holidays.funFact: Abraham Lincoln was famously born in a one-room log cabin, symbolizing humble beginnings.

holidays.name: Be Nasty Day
holidays.description: A tongue-in-cheek holiday encouraging people to be cheeky, bold, and a little mischievous (all in good fun, of course). It's a day for playful rudeness and shaking off politeness!
holidays.origin: Origin unknown but popularized by internet memes and social media to encourage sass and humor.
holidays.funFact: The sassiest tweets are often posted on Be Nasty Day, making it a viral social media celebration.

holidays.name: Seward's Day (Alaska)
holidays.description: This state holiday commemorates the 1867 signing of the treaty where the U.S. purchased Alaska from Russia, a.k.a 'Seward's Folly' because many thought buying Alaska was a mistake!
holidays.origin: Named after U.S. Secretary of State William H. Seward who negotiated the purchase of Alaska.
holidays.funFact: At the time, people mocked the purchase but Alaska turned out to be rich in natural resources like oil and gold!
